full_title_en: Rome II Diagnostic Criteria for Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
medium_description_en: Official Rome II criteria for the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome.
instructions_en: The <calculator id='4007'>Rome IV Criteria</calculator> are now recommended as an update to these criteria (May 2016).

seo.meta_description_en: The Rome II Diagnostic Criteria provides criteria for diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) within 3 month period.
seo.keywords_en: IBS, rome ii, rome iii, irritable bowel syndrome diagnosis

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en: The Rome II Criteria, developed through a literature review and consensus process, defined the diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) until the Rome III and subsequently Rome IV Criteria refined them. There remains no objective reference (i.e., ‘gold standard’) for the diagnosis.
how_to_use.why_use_en: The symptoms that define IBS are generally subjective and self-reported, making a classification system helpful. Moreover, there is some evidence to support the notion that patients who meet formal Rome criteria are more likely to respond to some therapies.

next_steps.advice_en: The Rome Criteria are helpful in classifying patients and for determining potential therapies.
next_steps.management_en: We are unaware of validated management algorithms using the Rome Criteria.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: IBS is a ‘rule-out’ diagnosis, which is to say all other possibilities must be ruled out first.

about.formula_en:
Patient must have at least 12 weeks of abdominal discomfort or pain, which need not be consecutive, in the preceding 12 months with at least 2 of following 3 features:

  • Relieved with defecation.
  • Onset associated with a change in stool frequency.
  • Onset associated with a change in stool form (appearance).

Original/Primary Reference.text: Drossman DA. The functional gastrointestinal disorders and the Rome II process. Gut. 1999;45(suppl II):II1–II5.

Other References.text: Comparison Table of Rome II and Rome III Adult Diagnostic Criteria.
Thompson WG, Longstreth GF, Drossman DA, et al. Functional bowel disorders and functional abdominal pain. Gut. 1999;45(suppl 2):II43–II47.
Longstreth GF, Thompson WG, Chey WD, et al. Functional bowel disorders. Gastroenterology. 2006;130:1489–1491.
Drossman DA. The functional gastrointestinal disorders and the Rome III process. Gastroenterology 2006;130:1377–1390.

creator_info.about_en: Douglas Drossman, MD, is professor emeritus of medicine and psychiatry at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine. He is founder, President Emeritus and Chief of Operations of the Rome Foundation. He is also the founder of the Drossman Center for the Education and Practice of Biopsychosocial Care and Drossman Consulting, LLC. Dr. Drossman has written over 500 articles and book chapters, has published two books, a GI procedure manual and a textbook of functional GI disorders (Rome I-IV), and serves on six editorial and advisory boards.
